occurrences.line_text: Come thou (quoth he) and see. So by and by
Suffise it then, thou Money God (quoth hee)
Nay, nay, thou greedie Tantalus (quoth he)
Sad end (quoth he) of life intemperate,
Loue haue I sure, (quoth she) but Lady none;
But mine is not (quoth she) like others wound;
Things oft impossible (quoth she) seeme, ere begonne.
Nought like (quoth she) for that same wretched boy
Ah read, (quoth Britomart) how is she hight?
Faire Angela (quoth she) men do her call,
Royally clad (quoth he) in cloth of gold,
Ah dearest God (quoth he) that is great woe,
That Lady is (quoth he) where so she bee,
Her well beseemes that Quest (quoth Satyrane)
That shall I you recount (quoth he) ywis,
Ah gentle Squire (quoth he) tell at one word,
T'haue seene, (quoth he) when as a monstrous beast
Faire Sir (quoth he) well may it you succeed,
This is (quoth he) the dolorous despight,
Take then to you this Dame of mine (quoth hee)
Then tell (quoth Blandamour) and feare no blame,
I saw (quoth she) a stranger knight, whose name
Ah gentle knights (quoth he) how may that bee,
Not one (quoth he) but many doe partake
Then since (quoth she) the terme of each mans life
Then this, Sir Saluage Knight (quoth he) areede;
Shame be his meede (quoth he) that meaneth shame.
(Quoth she) of all that euer hath bene knowen:
To tell (quoth she) that which ye see, needs not;
Through helpe (quoth she) of this old woman here
This mightie man (quoth he) whom you haue slaine,
He liues (quoth he) and his ï¿½mylia loues.
And yet (quoth she) a greater wrong remaines:
Ah woe is me, and well away (quoth hee)
To hope (quoth he) him soone to ouertake,
Within three daies (quoth hee) as I do here,
What mister wight (quoth he) and how far hence
What other right (quoth he) should you esteeme,
What other right (quoth he) should you esteeme,
Then sith ye needs (quoth he) will know my shame,
Her name (quoth he) they Radigund doe call,
Vnworthy sure (quoth he) of better day,
Ay me (quoth she) what wicked destinie?
Sayd I not then (quoth shee) erwhile aright,
Say on (quoth he) the secret of your hart:
Ah my deare Lord, what sight is this (quoth she)
Ten daies (quoth he) he graunted hath of grace,
That shall I vnto you (quoth he) bewray;
Not so; (quoth he) for yet when time doth serue,
What is that quest (quoth then Sir Artegall)
The Blattant Beast (quoth he) I doe pursew,
Now God you speed (quoth then Sir Artegall)
(Quoth he) I hold it no indignity;
Cowherd (quoth she) were not, that thou wouldst fly,
Full loth am I (quoth he) as now at earst,
His name (quoth he) if that thou list to learne,
Nathlesse (quoth he) if need doe not you bynd,
But where then is (quoth he halfe wrothfully)
In quyent disguise, full hard to be descride.
Who well it wards, and quyteth cuff with cuff:
A rude, misshapen, monstrous rablement,
Heaped together in rude rablement
The first troupe was a monstrous rablement
Was as the rest, a grysie rablement,
Whom soone as that vnruly rablement,
And mingled with the raskall rablement,
Go gather vp the reliques of thy race,
Of falshood, and root of Duessaes race.
To runne her timely race, whilst Phoebus pure
Sat downe to rest in middest of the race:
Whose wondrous faith, exceeding earthly race,
Whom well she knew to spring from heauenly race,
And thou faire ymp, sprong out from English race,
For well I wote, thou springst from ancient race
That Titan rose to runne his daily race:
He gan rencounter him in equall race.
Must now anew begin, like race to runne;
His race with reason, and with words his will,
So from immortall race he does proceede,
Most wretched woman, and of wicked race,
Like an huge Gyant of the Titans race,
Thy name Ã´ soueraine Queene, thy realme and race,
Tho Madan raignd, vnworthie of his race:
Such as Laomedon of Phoebus race did breed.
And Cormoyrants, with birds of rauenous race,
Their banket houses burne, their buildings race,
Be it worthy of thy race and royall sead,
For all thy Cities they shall sacke and race,
In gentle Ladies brest, and bounteous race
The daughter of Amphisa, who by race
Retyrd their steeds, to ronne in euen race:
Against that nation, from whose race of old
To haue rencountred him in equall race;
More swift then Myrrh' or Daphne in her race,
Gainst wofull Niobes vnhappy race,
Cannot recount, nor tell their hidden race,
But euermore some of the vertuous race
Return'd to heauen, whence she deriu'd her race;
Does race her castle quight.
Calling him great Osyris, of the race
For that they both like race in equall iustice runne.
For noble courage, and for hardie race,
She first was bred, and borne of heauenly race;
Of Gyants race, the sonne of Geryon,
And meeting him right in the middle race,
Of that vilde race, and stablished my peace.
Horrible, hideous, and of hellish race,
It is a Monster bred of hellishe race,
That sure he deem'd him borne of noble race.
Of what degree and what race he is growne.
Him ouertooke in middest of his race:
Some goodly person, and of gentle race,
Doth she exceede the rest of all her race;
And lastly all that Castle quite he raced,
Thinking at once both head and helmet to haue raced.
Was raced out, and Mal was now put in.
Raced, and made smooth fields now full of flowres?
And both his feet in fetters to an yron racke.
Of euill, may more notably be rad,
That by his grenning laughter mote farre off be rad.
Which was by him BELPHEBE rightly rad.
And eke the courser, whereuppon he rad,
That I would hide, will needs, I see, be rad.
They knew them selues, and both their persons rad:
The which of her owne name she called Radigone.
Her name (quoth he) they Radigund doe call,
Which when as Radigund there comming heard,
But Radigund her selfe, when she espide
Bold Radigund with sound of trumpe on hight,
But Radigund full of heart-gnawing griefe,
Artegall fights with Radigund
Euen so did Radigund with bootlesse paine
Seruing proud Radigund with true subiection;
Moue Radigund? who though she still haue worne
She fights with Radigund, her slaies,
Whereof when newes to Radigund was brought,
At last proud Radigund with fell despight,
He raft her hatefull head without remorse;
Without or robe, or rag, to hide his shame.
But rudely rag'd, and like a cruell Tygre far'd.
So rag'd Prince Arthur twixt his foemen twaine,
Charm'd those wild-beasts, that rag'd with furie mad.
Which when they all beheld they chaft and rag'd,
And rayl'd and rag'd, till she had all her poyson spent.
For wall'd it was with waues, which rag'd and ror'd
The more she rag'd, the more he did abide;
Being all rag'd and tatter'd, their disgraces
But aye the more he rag'd, the more his powre increast.
After his murdrous spoiles and bloudy rage allayd.
Yet kindling rage, her selfe she gathered round,
Who all in rage to see his skilfull might
The eye of reason was with rage yblent,
Spurring so hote with rage dispiteous,
His bloudie rage asswaged with remorse,
Forgetfull of the hungry rage, which late
And let her in; where of his cruell rage
Thus long the dore with rage and threats he bet,
Her piteous words might not abate his rage,
Her prayers nought preuaile, his rage is more of might.
Trembling through hasty rage, whe[n] choler in him sweld.
His eldest brother, burning all with rage
Who all in rage his Sea-god syre besought,
Leaue roaring, when in rage he for reuenge did earne.
That roaring all with rage, did lowd requere
Their puissant force, and cruell rage attonce,
An heard of Bulles, whom kindly rage doth sting,
Which is through rage more strong then both were erst;
Before their rage grew to so great vnrest,
From tyrans rage, and euer-dying dread,
Come gently, but not with that mighty rage,
So flam'd his eyne with rage and rancorous yre:
Exceeding rage enflam'd the furious beast,
Nathlesse with wonted rage he him aduaunced neare.
Fit to inflame faire Lady with loues rage,
Gan with new rage their shields to hew and cut;
Then fowle reuenging rage, and base contentious iarre.
With beastly brutish rage gan him assay,
Feare gaue her wings, and rage enforst my flight;
Which kindled once, his mother did more rage inspyre.
Auauntage, whilest his foe did rage most rife;
Eftsoones he gan to rage, and inly fret,
To see Pyrrochles there so rudely rage:
With liquid waues, fiers Vulcans rage to tame,
Whom when Pyrrochles saw, inflam'd with rage,
Haue secret powre, t'appease inflamed rage:
Horribly then he gan to rage, and rayle,
When rancour doth with rage him once engore,
That had not yet felt Cupides wanton rage,
Vespasian, that with great spoile and rage
Of the fraile flesh, relenting to their rage,
And carries into smoake with rage and horror great.
And halfe in rage, to be deluded thus,
And rule the Furyes, when they most do rage:
From prosecuting his reuenging rage;
For no no vsuall fire, no vsuall rage
Them yielded readie passage, and their rage surceast.
Fraile Ladies hart with loues consuming rage,
And in his rage his mother would haue slaine,
Broke into open fire and rage extreme,
In your auengement and dispiteous rage,
Together with impetuous rage and forse,
With roring rage, and sore him selfe does throng,
His mighty rage, and with imperious sway
With roaring rage; and dashing on all sides,
But he the more with furious rage was fyred,
And drawing both their swords with rage extreme,
They gan abate the rancour of their rage,
As when two Tygers prickt with hungers rage,
Which stirs vp anguish and contentious rage:
Into the hunters toile, doth rage and rore,
With so fell rage, her selfe she lightly gan
He all the way did rage at that same Squire,
All full of rage he gan to curse and sweare,
From all foure parts of heauen doe rage full sore,
The surging seas, when they do sorest rage,
They snuf, they snort, they bou[n]ce, they rage, they rore,
Which when he saw, he greatly grew in rage,
Whether by rage of waues, that neuer rest,
Her heart for rage did grate, and teeth did grin:
With furious rage, as if she had intended
She gan to storme, and rage, and rend her gall,
With that in rage she turn'd from him aside,
With greedy rage, and with their faulchins smot;
She forth did rome, whether her rage her bore,
Her burning tongue with rage inflamed hath,
Doe all attonce their thunders rage forth rent,
He gan to burne in rage, and friese in feare,
To his first rage, and yeeld to his despight;
For as he in his rage him ouerstrooke,
To him for aide, who long in vaine their rage withstands.
Till Artegall him seeing so to rage,
With bitter rage and fell contention,
He woxe halfe mad, and in that rage gan roue
Saue such as sudden rage him lent to smite,
That they to pitty turnd their former rage,
To rule the stubborne rage of passion blinde:
Cruell Typhaon, whose tempestuous rage
Whom when the Prince so felly saw to rage,
Tho all in rage, he on him streight did seaze,
The whiles the beast doth rage and loudly rore,
That with great rage he stoutly doth denay;
With cruell rage and dreadfull violence
In so great rage, that them in dongeon deepe
But he right well aware, his rage to ward,
Full cruelly the Beast did rage and rore,
And rage to quaile, he tooke a muzzell strong
And slake the heauenly fire, that raged euermore.
Rored, and raged to be vnder-kept:
Still stroue their stubborne rages to reuoke,
Yet at her speach their rages gan relent,
And thee their mother call to coole their kindly rages.
With his sharpe wheeles, in his first rages heat,
And euer fickle fortune rageth rife,
Which in these troubled bowels raignes, & rageth rife.
And rageth sore in each degree and state;
His goodly corps on ragged cliffs yrent,
All arm'd with ragged snubbes and knottie graine,
The mightie trunck halfe rent, with ragged rift
Did hang vpon the ragged rocky knees;
His garment nought but many ragged clouts,
Scattred with bushy thornes, and ragged breares,
The rolling billowes beat the ragged shore,
And ragged ribs of mountaines molten new,
My ragged rimes are all too rude and bace,
In ragged robes, and filthy disaray,
From whose rough vaut the ragged breaches hong,
Vile caytiue wretches, ragged, rude, deformd,
And threatneth downe to throw his ragged rift
His rugged flesh, and rent his ragged heare:
With him went Daunger, cloth'd in ragged weed,
With ragged monuments of times forepast,
Casts off his ragged skin and freshly doth him dight.
His word, which on his ragged shield was writ,
Vpon the ground in ragged rude attyre,
Made of straunge stuffe, but all to worne and ragged,
And catching her fast by her ragged weed,
How to reforme that ragged common-weale:
But catching vp in hand a ragged stone,
Vnmard with ragged mosse or filthy mud;
With ragged weedes, and lockes vpstaring hye,
As raging flames who striueth to suppresse.
From raging spoile of lawlesse victors will?
The swelling Splene, and Frenzy raging rife,
Therewith redoubled was his raging yre,
Whom when the raging Sarazin espide,
And throw in raging sea with roaring threat.
He cryde, as raging seas are wont to rore,
Inflam'd with wrath, his raging blade he heft,
When raging passion with fierce tyrannie
Whom raging windes threatning to make the pray
With her, who so will raging Furor tame,
And bit his tawny beard to shew his raging ire.
That welnigh molt his hart in raging yre,
But with his raging armes he rudely flasht,
The carefull seruant, striuing with his raging Lord.
But th'other was Impatience, arm'd with raging flame.
And streight they saw the raging surges reard
My raging smart, ne ought my flame relent,
And in their raging surquedry disdaynd,
Raging within the waues: thereby he weend
The raging billowes, that on euery syde
Like as in sommers day when raging heat
Whose raging rigour neither steele nor bras
Or raging fire of loue to woman kind,
Did mollifie, and calme her raging heat.
Of breath, their raging rigour to relent,
The raging seas, and makst the stormes to flie;
The raging Buls rebellow through the wood,
And all the raging seas for ioy forgot to rore.
Beare off the burden of her raging yre;
And raging flames, that many foes shall reare,
That she her shield through raging smart of it
Like raging Ino, when with knife in hand
And inly burnt with flames most raging whot,
But he doth with his raging brond diuide
Which he had spilt, and all to rags yrent,
Their feet vnshod, their bodies wrapt in rags,
In rags, that naked nigh she did appeare,
Rude was his garment, and to rags all rent,
Torne all to rags, and rent with many a wound,
Ruffled and fowly raid with filthy soyle,
A shaking feuer raignd continually:
There raignd a solemne silence ouer all,
And him that raignd, into his rowme thrust downe,
Tho Madan raignd, vnworthie of his race:
What time king Ryence raign'd, and dealed right,
Which raignd so many yeares victorious,
And all delight does raigne, much more then this?
Then did he raigne alone, when he none equall knew.
During the raigne of Maximinian;
For during Saturnes ancient raigne it's sayd,
And raigned long in great felicitie,
After him raigned Guitheline his hayre,
Next him Tenantius raigned, then Kimbeline,
Of fatall Thebes, of Rome that raigned long,
Which in these troubled bowels raignes, & rageth rife.
Thou God of winds, that raignest in the seas,
That raignest also in the Continent,
And raignst in blis emongst thy blessed Saintes,
And cry, and curse, and raile, and rend her heare,
Large floods of bloud adowne their sides did raile;
But sober Guyon, hearing him so raile,
Shee with her rod did softly smite the raile,
But Talus hearing her so lewdly raile,
And sharpely at him to reuile and raile,
His ruffin raiment all was staind with blood,
Next him king Leyr in happie peace long raind,
And angry Ioue an hideous storme of raine
And euer-drizling raine vpon the loft,
Such wondrous science in mans wit to raine
At last when life recouer'd had the raine,
As it had deawed bene with timely raine:
Through launched, forth her bleeding life does raine,
Which gotten was but hate. So loue does raine
That streight did lead to Plutoes griesly raine:
Their strokes did raine, yet did he neuer quaile,
Then gan the bloudie brethren both to raine:
In whose sad time bloud did from heauen raine:
After whom Lago, and Kinmarke did raine,
All which successiuely by turnes did raine;
That whylome in diuinest wits did raine,
Then shall Cadwallin dye, and then the raine
Then shall a royall virgin raine, which shall
But soone as life recouered had the raine,
Like as a fearefull Doue, which through the raine,
His watry eyes, drizling like deawy raine,
Hight Nausa, there he many yeares did raine,
Did raine into her lap an hony dew,
To range the field, and victorlike to raine,
And poureth forth a sudden shoure of raine,
At length breakes downe in raine, and haile, and sleet,
Such heauenly iustice doth among them raine,
I will suppresse, that they no more may raine;
To meeke obeysance of loues mightie raine,
Vntill he had her settled in her raine,
And impotent desire of men to raine,
And hung the head, soone as few drops of raine
In all this forrest, and wyld wooddie raine:
Who all this while at will did range and raine,
During which space she there as Princess rained,
Whom great griefe made forget the raines to hold
The maistring raines out of her weary wrest,
Haling her palfrey by the hempen raines.
Fearing least he at length the raines would lend
And by her hellish science raisd streightway
Raisd warre, and him in battell ouerthrew:
So is his soueraine honour raisde to heauens hight.
And raise my thoughts too humble and too vile,
A fordonne wight from dore of death mote raise,
Of doughtie knights, whom Faery land did raise,
And raise againe to life the hart, that she did thrill.
Endeuouring my dreadded name to raise
Some thought to raise themselues to high degree,
And of them both did foy and tribute raise,
Whom antique history so high doth raise,
They all were bound to all posterities to raise.
Which hunt for honor, raised from below,
This cruell conflict raised thereabout,
And all attonce her beastly body raizd
His bodie leane and meagre as a rake,
Bene in his ashes raked vp, and hid,
And farre away, amid their rakehell bands,
Now like a Ram, faire Helle to peruart,
For that same golden fleecy Ram, which bore
And ramd with bullet round, ordaind to kill,
And trampling the fine element, would fiercely rampe.
A ramping Lyon rushed suddainly,
And ramping on his shield, did weene the same
Came ramping forth with proud presumpteous gate,
As hundred ramping Lyons seem'd to rore,
He rampt vpon him with his rauenous pawes,
As when two rams stird with ambitious pride,
With gaping mouth at her ran greedily,
That all the poison ran about his chaw;
And ran towards the far rebownded noyce,
And trembling horrour ran through euery ioynt,
Whom when his Lady saw, to him she ran
The crudled cold ran to her well of life,
And fiercely ran at him with rigorous might:
Ran through his mouth with so importune might,
And after, all the raskall many ran,
And reason with foole-hardize ouer ran;
And shyning blade vnsheathd, with which he ran
Attonce vpon him ran, and him beset
Emongst them ran, and falling them beforne,
Purloynd both steed and speare, and ran away full light.
Adieu, but nimbly ran her wonted course
That deadly daunger, soone atweene them ran;
An armed knight, that towards him fast ran,
He ran on foot, as if in lucklesse warre
Swift Atalanta, when through craft he her out ran.
Ran to his hart, and all his sence dismayd,
That as the winde ran vnderneath his lode,
Binding her sister, she to him ran hastily.
Like two mad dogs they ran about the lands,
That the hoare waters from his frigot ran,
Ran towards, to deuoure those vnexpected guests.
When Britomart him saw, she ran a pace
And to her weapon ran, in minde to gride
And eke the Redcrosse knight ran to the stownd,
Strongly the straunge knight ran, and sturdily
Knotted with bloud, in bounches rudely ran,
Vnto his reskew ran, and greedily him sped.
And at her ran: she hauing him descryde,
So ran the Geauntesse vnto the fight;
For fire in earnest, ran with fearefull speed,
He ran as fast, as both his feete could beare,
And ran away, ran with himselfe away:
And ran away, ran with himselfe away:
And to her ran with hasty egernesse,
They to his succour ran with readie ayd:
Ran hastily, to weete what did him ayle.
But the more strong and stiffely that he ran,
And ran at him with all his might and maine;
Full many others at him likewise ran:
Gan fewter, and against her fiercely ran.
Ran, till he came to th'end of all his way,
Ran forth in hast with hideous outcry,
She ran in hast his life to haue bereft:
The whiles his life ran foorth in bloudie streame,
She to him ran, and him with streight embras
And Placidas, they both vnto him ran,
Ran fierce at me, that fire glaunst from his horses hoofe.
In three great riuers ran, and many countreis scowrd.
Together ran with ready speares in rest.
Eftsoones the people all to harnesse ran,
She at the first encounter on him ran
But ran to meete him forth, to know his tidings somme.
So ran they all, as they had bene at bace,
He ran still on, thinking to follow fast
He at him ran, with ready speare in rest:
She at her ran with all her force and might,
Ran with her fast away vnto his mew,
Vp to the rocke he ran, and thereon flew
And ran into the Hall, where he did weene
From whose sterne presence they diffused ran,
Vnto her ran with greedie great desyre,
Against him stoutly ran, as nought afeard,
But coucht his speare, and ran at him amaine.
Ran after fast, to reskue the distressed mayde.
With that ran at him, as he would deuoure
Vpon him ran; who being well prepard,
But after him the wyld man ran apace
That after him he ran with zealous haste,
Vpon him ran, and thrust it all attone
Against him ran; but th'one did misse his marke,
Which Coridon first hearing, ran in hast
He ran at him enrag[e]d in stead of being frayde.
Vnto the entrance ran: where the bold knight
So full of ioy, streight forth she ran in hast
But forth in hast ran to the straunger Mayd;
With his sharpe steele, and ran at him amaine
And more for ranck despight, then for great paine,
The seely man seeing him ryde so rancke,
Which knitting their rancke braunches part to part,
With him went Hope in rancke, a handsome Mayd,
Marcht in one rancke, yet an vnequall paire:
Like to a rancke of piles, that pitched are awry.
Three ranckes of yron teeth enraunged were,
Ranckled so sore, and festred inwardly,
